awd_titl_txt: MRI: Development of a Dynamic Material Processing and Testing Instrument
awd_abstract_narration:
This Major Research Instrumentation Award will support the development of a dynamic materials processing and test instrument that will allow the safe and detailed examination of highly dynamic materials processing in a conventional laboratory environment.  This is intended to dramatically increase access to dynamic materials testing and allow innovation in dynamic processes.  Highly dynamic processes that rely on intense pressures over short time are uncommon in research laboratories and almost unknown in manufacturing processes.  It is important to understand dynamic material behavior both for fundamental reasons and because it is common in ballistics, shock and processes like machining.  Also, dynamic processes can allow the development of materials structures and properties that are difficult or impossible to access with conventional processes.  This can lead to energy efficient processes and lighter weight transportation components; both outcomes can reduce atmospheric carbon emission. This program will also have positive impact on the STEM workforce by demonstrating to K-12 students that very creative, even disruptive, opportunities exist in engineering and providing the broad technical community a platform for innovation and training.

The new instrument will be based on the Vaporizing Foil Actuator (VFA) method of developing high pressures (>1 GPa) and high sample speeds (>1km/s).  The velocity field during launch, impact or forming can be measured at up to 16 points using a multiplexed photonic Doppler velocimetry system that is integral to the instrument.  This system will find application in a wide variety of experimental studies on topics including: high pressure phase transformations, impact welding, dynamic powder consolidation, residual stress and springback reduction, dynamic formability, dynamic embossing and shock hardening.  Impact welding, for example, can weld metals that cannot be joined by fusion methods and this instrument can encourage the commercial deployment of this technique.  The instrument will also dramatically reduce the difficulty and expense in fundamental studies of material behavior (plasticity, spall, fracture, etc.) at high strain rates and short times.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The Major Research Instrument acquisition under the program Development of a Dynamic Material Processing and Testing Instrument has contributed significantly to our collective understanding of the role of shock and impulse in metal forming and characterization, with 22 peer reviewed publications now in print on topics of impact welding, forming, residual stress modifications and spalling that are directly related to the work.  This investment has also catalyzed broad impacts in multiple arenas including the development of students and workforce ranging from undergraduates to industrial practitioners and the growth of new advanced manufacturing fields based upon impulse-based manufacturing.  The core activities of this grant were centered on the development of new types of compact and relatively simple equipment for the generation of high speed in flyers or shock loading directly and diagnostic instrumentation to measure flyer and sample speeds.  The core designs for compact impulse systems (see Fig 1) pioneered in this grant have been adapted and more refined adaptations have been developed for use at Oak Ridge National Lab and at the LIFT Manufacturing USA Institute. 

Innovative new methods for material joining and testing have been pioneered with the NSF-MRI equipment. Significant achievements include:

  • development of low-energy solid-state welding techniques that may replace rivets in aircraft joining (see Fig 2), 
  • a new method for joining multiple (over 30) thin (10-30 micron thick) foils as may be important for electrification, 
  • use of chemical augmentation to foil or laser impulse to reduce the amount and voltage of electrically stored energy and 
  • a new concept for ballistically-driven solid-state additive manufacturing has been demonstrated (see Fig 3).               

This core facility has been instrumental in the education of students and workforce at multiple levels including demonstrations for high school students, 3 undergraduate capstone projects, at least 10 undergraduate employees, provided facilities instrumental in 10 PhD theses and was used to host international student engagement.  It has been a cornerstone for external engagement.  Significant achievements include: 

  • development of core equipment elements by a Brazilian student collaboration (Fig 4), 
  • a collaboration with IIT-Bombay that led to a grant in an OSU-IIT-B gateway program,
  • SBIR/STTR programs have been run on the equipment for external companies and some of this has led to new joint publications on the fundamental nature of laser shock peening.  

These interactions are core to a small, but developing, international community that is exemplified by the robust International Impulse Forming group (http://i2fg.org) and special sessions on impulse manufacturing that have been hosted by, for example the International Conference on the Technology of Plasticity.  

This investment and the equipment will have a strong legacy.  The equipment is now being moved to a multi-user facility at Ohio State?s Center for Design and Manufacturing Excellence (http://cdme.osu.edu) where it will be managed in a professionally supported cost-center model.  

 


Last Modified: 12/30/2021
Modified by: Glenn S Daehn

Images (1 of )
  • Commercialized compact impulse system that is inspired by the NSF-MRI Design.
    Applied Impulse, Inc.
    Creative Commons
    Glenn S Daehn
    Compact Impulse System
  • Solid-state impact welding of aerospace aluminum alloys with external coatings intact. Machining removes joining surfaces and provides 300�m standoff gap. Failure and fatigue strengths exceed those of rivets and failure mode is through parent material (right). No heat affected zone present.
    Brian Thurston, OSU
    Creative Commons
    Glenn S Daehn
    Solid-state Aluminum Welding
  • Concept (left) and preliminary results on Ballistic Additive Manufacturing (BAM), which can build solid structures by sequential high velocity impact welding.
    Jianxiong Li, Ohio State
    Creative Commons
    Glenn S Daehn
    Ballistic Additive Manufacturing
  • Brazilian visiting students, Jose Paiva and Mateus Ferreira constructing Photon Doppler Velocimetry circuit with schematic on left.
    Geoff Taber, Ohio State
    Creative Commons
    Glenn S Daehn
    Photonic Doppler velocimetry & students
